column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=6. Conclusions
#Text=Based on the DH model , this study proposed a universal algorithm for finding an inverse kinematics closed-form solution .
#Text=This algorithm divided the inverse kinematics problem related to robots with a closed-form solution into three sub-problems assuming that the algebraic equation had a formula solution .
#Text=The solvability conditions for the three types of sub-problems were analyzed to derive a formula solution .
#Text=If a serial robot can be described with these three types of sub-problems , the robot will definitely have a closed-form solution .
#Text=Meanwhile , the formula solution based on such a problem could quickly solve for all the joint angles .
#Text=This method was not only applicable to six-DOF robots with a closed-form solution but also to low-DOF robots with the same solution form .

#Text=In addition , establishing an algorithm based on the DH model provides a concise and efficient tool for selecting sub-problems and a real-time inverse kinematics solution for the motion controller of a serial robot .
#Text=To verify the correctness and real-time performance of the algorithm , we presented four experimental designs .
#Text=The first three experiments were conducted on MATLAB with a series of robot to verify the completeness , universality , and continuity of this algorithm .
#Text=In the first experiment , the completeness of the algorithm was verified .

#Text=The experiment used a low-degree-of-freedom robot with closed inverse solutions to prove that the algorithm could solve its closed inverse solution , and the algorithm would be terminated for the robot without closed inverse solutions to avoid infinite loop .
#Text=This was used to prove the completeness of the algorithm .
#Text=In the second experiment , two uncommon robots were constructed through using some basic problems , but the closed inverse solution could still be solved .
#Text=Therefore , it could be known that the closed inverse solution of the series robots constructed by basic problems could be solved .

#Text=Meanwhile , for these robots whose structure was not changed but the link parameter was changed , the closed inverse solution of them could also be solved correctly , which indicates that the algorithm had certain versatility in solving the closed inverse solution problem .
#Text=In the third experiment , the common Puma560 robot was used as the experimental object .
#Text=In the experiment , a spatial curve was planned .
#Text=The correct joint angle sequence was obtained and the changes of the joint angle curve were continuously without jumping after been inversely solved by the algorithm .
#Text=Which indicates that the algorithm could guarantee the continuity of its mapping on the inverse solution problem .

#Text=The fourth experiment was conducted on a six-DOF robotic platform built using a Beckhoff-C6920 controller and an RGM motor to verify the real-time performance of the algorithm using the above hardware platform .
#Text=The spatial and joint positions were computed with a close-loop cycle of 2 ms and were transmitted to the motor via CanOpen .
#Text=The results demonstrated the ability of the algorithm to solve the three sub-problems within a specified cycle and to compute the appropriate joint angles .
#Text=Moreover , the curve was continuous .
#Text=This paper used a completely new approach to study the inverse kinematics of serial robots .
#Text=In this study , the conditions for the existence of the closed-form inverse kinematic solution of a serial robot were completed and the basic theory of robotics was perfected .
#Text=Based on this method , a general closed-form inverse kinematics algorithm based on the DH model was implemented , which had not been done in previous studies .
#Text=Importantly , this method is a general-purpose algorithm that can be used in industrial fields in real time .
#Text=This increases the versatility of the universal serial robot motion controller .
#Text=However , the algorithm still has shortcomings .
#Text=First , the algorithm only targets serial robots and the moving joints are not included in the solution model .
#Text=This limits the scope of application of the algorithm , due to its inability to solve the cases of SCARA robots or other parallel robots .
#Text=In addition , the algorithm cannot solve the problem when the robot passes through a singular point ; singular points are avoided via restrictions implemented in the software .
#Text=Moreover , because the algorithm is a purely analytical method , it is difficult to combine with other numerical methods to solve the problem of singular points .
